position.marginalia_text: Historici, et Jurisconsulti maximè pragmatici. Justinus, et Neander: cu[m[ Plutarchi vitis; et
Gandini Stratagematis: quasi instar totius Gra[e]cia[e].

marginalia.translation: Historians and lawyers are pragmatists in particular. Justin and Michael Neander: with Plutarch's 'Lives' and Gandino's 'Stratagemata': as if equal to the whole of Greece.

position.marginalia_text: / Theise boyes dare say to your face: Alas, it cannot be in you, that is in them. They ar younger, bigger, stronger, quicker, or able to endure Labour, ritcher, in higher office. What predominant, or Equipollent for all these? Noman, so continent, hardie, swift, daily daily exercised, how erlie refined, as he should be.
{ Nihil in Rom. Historia magis pragmaticum, quàm Mithridatis regis. Epistola, et Oratio illa apud Salustiu[m]: ha[e]c apud Justinum, Libro 38.

marginalia.translation: Nothing in Roman history was more pragmatic than king Mithridates. The epistles and that speech in Sallust: these in Justin, book 38.

position.marginalia_text: { Mihi egregiè conducunt Juliani Ca[e]sares: Guicciardini principes quasi depicti: Quinctus de petitione Consulatus: Marcus de prouincia administranda:
Sallustius de Rep. ordinanda. Plutarchi Politica: Xenophontis Hieron.

marginalia.translation: For me, the Julian emperors are extraordinary expedient: portrayed as if Guiccardini's princes: Cicero to Quintus, 'On running for the consulship': to Marcus, 'On administering the province': Sallust, 'On regulating the Republic'. Plutarch's 'Politics': Xenophon's 'On Hiero'.

position.marginalia_text: Multi egregij, admirabiles, quicquid volunt: sed mihi opus est ad unguem Eutropius, et Suetonius: Ca[e]sar, et Tacitus. Aut da Magistros. Justinianum, Bartholu[m], Durandu[m]; et

marginalia.translation: Many extraordinary and admirable people wish for something: but for me it is useful to learn by heart Eutropius and Suetonius; Caesar and Tacitus. Or give me magistrates. Justinian, Bartholus, and Durand; and finally my political pragmatist Bodin.

position.marginalia_text: Necessaria etiam ad unguem Althusij ars Juris propter memoriam: Hopperi ciuilis ratio propter illuminatu[m] discursum: Vigelij repertorium, et ius controuersum propter expeditam, certamq[ue] Praxin: [p. 198: et Jureconsultoru[m] Logica, alia[e]q[ue] Freigij Analyses propter pra[e]sentem Legu[m], Canonu[m]q[ue] Analysin. Semperq[ue] recordandum, ipsum Jurisconsulti A.B.C. esse regulas vtriusq[ue] Juris, cum Decio, et Dyno: qua[e] sunt in omni pragmatico discursu, disputatione, praxi frequentissima[e]: Cum regulis etiam Brocardicis Chauferi, id est, verbatim regulis magistralibus Speculatoris, in aureo Breuiario.]

marginalia.translation: It is also necessary to memorise by heart Althusius' art of law by means of memory: Hopper's civil reason by means of illuminated discourse: Virgil's repertoire and the legal compilation by means of expediency and certain praxis: [p. 198: and the logic of lawyers and other analyses of Freigius by means of existing analysis of laws and canon [laws]. [p. 198: And it must always be remembered that the actual A.B.C. of the lawyer is the rules of both laws, with Filippo Decio and Magellanus Dinus: which appear most frequently in every pragmatic discourse, disputation and practice. Also with Kaufer's 'Regulae brocardicae juris', that is, with the expert rules of the spectator word for word, in the 'Golden Breviary'.]
